Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: P2C2 -- Statistical estimation of past ice sheet volumes from paleo-sea level records
Award.AbstractNarration:
The PIs propose to develop a statistical model for inferring past mean global sea level (GSL) and ice sheet volumes from geological indicators of changes in local sea levels. This model will employ a Bayesian statistical framework to combine geological observations and their uncertainties with a geophysical model of the spatial and temporal sea level patterns associated with different meltwater sources. The proposed work focuses on three specific applications:
(1) evaluating the contribution of different ice sheets to high GSL during the Last Interglacial stage, ~130-115 thousand years ago;
(2) assessing ice sheet history from the Last Glacial Maximum (LGM) to the present, in particular estimating the net ice volume change across this time interval and assessing the relative contributions of the Laurentide and Antarctic ice sheets to meltwater pulse 1a at ~14.3 thousand years ago; and
(3) over a broader sweep of the Quaternary and Pliocene, investigating the relationship between Northern and Southern hemisphere ice volumes and paleoclimate proxies.

The geological record of past ice sheet responses to climate change can serve as a key data source for testing forward physical models of ice sheet dynamics under different climate scenarios. The model developed in this project will be an effort to synthesize such a data set, evaluate its associated uncertainties, and employ it to strengthen understanding of the relationship between key climate parameters (such as polar and circum-polar temperatures) and ice sheet stability.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Sea level changes are one of the most sensitive indicators of climate change, both in the modern world and the distant past. Under the funding provided by this proposal our group has been active in a variety of studies related to the global average sea level rise during the last century and the last few millennia and also the geographic variability in sea level change during both these time periods. When ice sheets melt or ocean warms or ocean circulation changes, sea level changes will be highly variable geographically - that is, the world's oceans do not act like a bathtub where the addition of water leads to a uniform change in the height of the bath. Estimates of the global mean sea level rise or the geographic variability in sea level change are related in the sense that an understanding of processes that give rise to the latter can improve estimates of the global average. Our projects have taken full advantage of this relationship.

The most high profile result emerging from our work is the paper of Hay et al. (Nature, 2015). This study combined sophisticated statistical methods with physical modeling of the processes that give rise to sea level variability to revisit estimates of global sea level change over the last century. The study concluded that previous estimates of this change for the period 1901-1990 (1.5-1.8 mm/yr) were 20-30% too high, while confirming previous estimates of global sea level rise over the last two decades. While this may appear to be good news, it is not - by reducing the estimate of global sea level rise from 1901-1990, the study concluded that the acceleration of global mean sea level rise from the 20th to 21st century was higher than previously thought and this has implications for efforts to project changes in sea level over the next century. The smaller estimate of global mean sea level rise for 1901-1990 was important for another reason. The 5th assessment report of the IPCC included an estimate of the total sea level rise for this period based on measurements and modeling of individual sources and this esitmate was smaller that the estimate based on analyses of sea level measurements over the same period by about 0.5 mm/yr, and this difference defined a so-called missing ice mass problem. This missing mass problem disappears when one adopts the lower estimate of global mean sea level rise from 1901-1990 published by Hay et al. (2015).

A follow on study led by Bob Kopp used a similar statistic approach to estimate global mean sea level change over the past 2-3 millennia. The study concluded that the global mean sea level change since 1900 was about the same as the total peak-to-peak sea level fluctuation in the several thosuand years prior to 1900, and thus demonstrated that sea level changes since 1900 are highly anomalous.

Finally, the group was also active in revisiting the connection between global sea level changes and Earth rotation. The great oceanographer Walter Munk published a paper in 2001 that argued that the level of sea level rise in the 20th century would have produced perturbations in Earth rotation that were not observed in astronomical and geodetic observations. This issue defined an enigma that has motivated significant work and discussions within the global change community. In one study, Mitrovica et al.
